feed.title: Combined summary - ACK NACK utACK "Concept ACK"

entry.title: Combined summary - ACK NACK utACK "Concept ACK"
entry.summary: During code reviews for the Bitcoin software, various types of acknowledgments are used to indicate levels of review and approval. Wladimir introduced the terms 'Concept ACK', 'utACK', and 'Tested ACK' to describe different levels of review and testing completed. Additionally, he explained that 'NACK' is used to reject a code change with an explanation provided. However, he noted that outsiders may struggle to understand these terms without context and suggested creating a document explaining them.A user on the Bitcoin-development mailing list requested documentation explaining key terminology used within code reviews. In response, Wladimir provided a list of abbreviations and explained their meanings. He also mentioned that a document on this would be useful as it may not be easily understood by outsiders. The user appreciated Wladimir's response and offered to draft something based on the thread. Sergio Lerner also asked if there were any other acronyms or if these were documented somewhere. In December 2014, Wladimir sent an email to Bitcoin core developer Jeff Garzik expressing a "Concept ACK" regarding an idea proposed. This meant that he agreed with the overall direction of the proposal but acknowledged that the code changes had not been reviewed or tested. However, he also suggested that the code may need rewriting or further review before implementation. Jeff Garzik is an open-source evangelist and works at BitPay, Inc., a company that provides bitcoin payment processing services.It is important to note that when communicating with others, especially in professional settings, it is helpful to be clear and concise with language and terminology. Providing documentation or resources can also aid in better communication and understanding between parties.
